;;白宫国家安全发言人约翰·柯比 (John Kirby) 在华盛顿白宫新闻秘书卡琳·让-皮埃尔 (Karine Jean-Pierre) 新闻发布会上发表讲话，美国，2023 年 10 月 3 日。路透社/Leah Millis/档案照片;
;

;在伊斯兰激进组织哈马斯袭击以色列后，美国政府无意派遣军队，但它白宫发言人周一表示，将保护美国在该地区的利益。

;

;白宫国家安全委员会发言人约翰·柯比表示，“毫无疑问，伊朗在支持哈马斯方面存在一定程度的共谋”，但乔·拜登总统的政府尚未看到伊朗直接参与策划当前袭击的切实证据。

;

;柯比告诉记者，白宫预计以色列会提出更多安全要求，并将尽力尽快满足这些需求。

;

;他还表示，“现在说我们已经停止”沙特阿拉伯和以色列关系正常化的努力还为时过早，但仍应鼓励这种外交。

;;在周六（10 月 7 日）哈马斯激进分子袭击和以色列报复后，多家国际航空公司已暂停飞往特拉维夫的航班。菲奥娜·琼斯报道。;
;;
;< Small style="color: #999;">;2023 年 7 月 11 日，在以色列罗德的本古里安国际机场，人们挥舞以色列国旗，抗议以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡及其民族主义联合政府的司法改革。 REUTERS/Amir Cohen/File Photo;
;

;主要国际航空公司暂停或减少往返特拉维夫的航班，而俄罗斯则禁止夜间飞往以色列的航班。 /middle-east/israel-retaliates-after-hamas-attacks-deaths-pass-1100-2023-10-09/">;哈马斯武装分子周末发动的突然袭击;以及冲突升级的威胁引发了安全担忧.

;

;根据航班跟踪网站 Flightradar24 的数据，截至周一晚上，以色列约 50% 的特拉维夫定期航班周日没有运营，周一取消了三分之一的航班。

;

;美国航空公司联合航空 ;(UAL.O); 和美国航空 ;(AAL.O); 在美国联邦航空管理局敦促航空公司谨慎行事后，暂停了飞往以色列的直飞航班。达美航空 ;(DAL.N); 周一表示将取消飞往 和 的航班从以色列起飞的航班直至本月底。

;

;许多欧洲航空公司也取消了航班。

;

;以色列国家航空公司;以色列航空; ;(ELAL.TA); 是个例外 - 增加了更多航班，将预备役军人从世界各地带回，协助该国历史上最大规模的动员。

;

;伊斯兰组织哈马斯的武装分子在周六的袭击中杀害了至少 900 人，并绑架了数十名人质 ;袭击;是数十年来最致命的此类入侵，促使以色列通过袭击巴勒斯坦飞地加沙进行报复。

;

;以色列的旅游业由特拉维夫的海滩和派对爱好者推动随着航班取消的增加，前往耶路撒冷等景点的历史之旅将受到重大打击。根据经合组织的数据，旅游业占总就业人数的 3.6%。

;

;美国邮轮运营商皇家加勒比;(RCL.N); 和嘉年华;(CCL.N) ;表示他们已经“调整”了在以色列地区的行程。

;

;“到目前为止，客户还没有取消订单，但他们对旅行更加谨慎。我们收到了很多订单团体旅游和旅游公司 Intrepid Travel 的美洲区总裁马特·伯纳 (Matt Berna) 表示：“我们收到了有关安全的询问。”

;

;美国联邦航空管理局 (FAA)、欧盟航空安全局 (European Union Aviation Safety Agency) 和以色列航空管理局 (Israel the Aviation Authority) 等监管机构敦促航空公司谨慎行事不过，俄罗斯以所谓的“政治和军事局势不稳定”为由，限制了格林威治标准时间 0900 点之前飞往以色列的航班，并建议航空公司监控白天的风险。

;

;以色列民航局要求航空公司“审查当前的安全和威胁信息”，并改变了一些空中交通路线。它指出延误是预料之中的，并建议航空公司携带额外的燃油。

;

;美国航空公司通常从纽约、芝加哥、华盛顿和迈阿密等主要城市提供直飞航班。

;

;这三个城市中美国航空公司中，联合航空的风险最大。根据路透社对 Cirium 数据的分析，截至 12 月的季度，以色列产能占其全球计划产能的 1.9%。美国航空的风险敞口最低，以色列占同期全球运力的 0.4%。

;

;美国航空股周一下跌，达美航空收盘下跌 4.6%，美国航空下跌 4%，联合航空下跌 4.9% %。

;

;;在欧洲;，法国航空 ;(AIRF.PA);、葡萄牙的 TAP 和芬兰的芬兰航空 ;(FIA1S.HE); 暂停直飞航班。挪威航空 ;(NAS.OL); 取消了从哥本哈根和斯德哥尔摩飞往特拉维夫的航班本周，瑞安航空 ;(RYA.I); 取消了截至周三的航班。;

;英国易捷航空;(EZJ.L);暂停飞往特拉维夫的航班周日和周一，并表示将调整未来几天的航班时刻。

;

;匈牙利廉价航空公司 Wizz Air ;(WIZZ.L); 取消了往返特拉维夫的航班，直至另行通知。

;

;“Wizz Air 的运营会计是受影响最严重的集团爱尔兰经纪公司 Goodbody 表示，该航班约占以色列 10 月份总运力的 9.4%，并且……约占该航空公司总航班时刻表的 2.3%。

;

;汉莎航空 ;(LHAG.DE); 也是对以色列影响最大的航空公司之一，该航空公司取消了周一之前往返特拉维夫的航班。; p>;

;维珍航空表示将继续运营部分航班，但客户可以在 10 月 15 日之前重新预订或要求退款。

;

;由于冲突导致油价上涨，英国航空公司股价周一下跌，燃料是航空公司最大的成本之一。英国航空母公司 IAG ;(ICAG.L);、Wizz Air 和 easyJet 均已关闭下跌约6%。

;

;海南航空;(600221.SS);是唯一一家在中国和以色列之间运营航班的中国航空公司，其他从香港和韩国起飞的航空公司取消了飞往特拉维夫的航班。

;

;海南航空表示将继续运营连接北京和南方科技中心的航班深圳飞往特拉维夫的航班。

;

;埃及航空往返开罗和特拉维夫的航班已无限期暂停。

;;美国前财政部长 Jack Lew 在国际货币基金组织春季期间题为“改革欧元区：欧洲内外的观点”的小组中发表讲话2018年4月19日在美国华盛顿举行的会议。路透社/Aaron P. Bernstein/档案照片;
;

;美国参议院可能会确认乔·拜登总统的驻以色列大使提名人、前财政部长杰克卢，参议院助手周一表示，最快下周，华盛顿将对哈马斯枪手周末对这个犹太国家发动的毁灭性袭击做出回应。

;

;参议院外交关系委员会宣布将举行卢的确认听证会10 月 18 日。

;

;助手们表示，在众议院占微弱多数的民主党人希望尽快在周四投票确认卢的任命。

;

;拜登 ;9月份提名卢;担任该职位，此举立即赢得了他的同事的赞扬民主党人。

;

;由于担任过内阁秘书，卢此前曾接受过参议院确认。

;

;除了担任财政部长外，卢在前民主党总统巴拉克·奥巴马手下还曾担任白宫官员参谋长兼负责管理和资源的副国务卿。

;

;自 7 月汤姆·尼德斯离职以来，该职位一直空缺。

;;2023 年 10 月 9 日，一枚从加沙地带发射的火箭袭击了以色列南部斯德洛特附近的地区。REUTERS/Amir Cohen ;
;

;美军正在向以色列“激增”新的防空系统、弹药和其他安全援助供应，以帮助其应对前所未有的周末;哈马斯发动袭击;，美国高级国防官员周一表示。

;

;“飞机已经起飞关闭，”这位不愿透露姓名的美国官员对五角大楼记者表示。

;

;“我们正在大力支持以色列......我们与以色列同行保持持续不断的联系，以确定并随后提供支持他们最紧迫的需求。”

;

;美国尚未详细说明以色列安全援助请求的范围。但美国国防官员表示，华盛顿正在与国防工业联系，以加快处理以色列未决订单，并研究美军自己的库存，以帮助填补以色列的缺口。

;

;该官员似乎也消除了对美国的担忧。在输送以色列的同时，可能会难以向以色列供应;反映了圣战组织伊斯兰组织实施的袭击;州。

;

;美国总统乔·拜登表示至少有 11 名;在以色列被杀的人中有美国公民;，并补充说哈马斯人质中可能有美国公民。

;

;“我已指示我的团队与以色列同行就人质危机的各个方面进行合作，包括共享情报，”拜登在白宫发布的一份声明中表示。

;

;美国高级国防官员表示，目前还没有发现任何证据表明伊朗是以色列袭击事件的幕后黑手，华尔街日报报道称，伊朗安全官员帮助策划了这一事件。

;

;“当然，伊朗也在其中。伊朗多年来一直向哈马斯和真主党提供支持。但目前我们没有任何信息证实《华尔街日报》报道的具体情况。”该官员表示。

;;美国总统乔·拜登在纽约举行的第 78 届联合国大会期间与以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡举行双边会晤，美国，2023 年 9 月 20 日。路透社/凯文·拉马克/档案照片;
;

;美国总统乔·拜登和以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡，即使在最好的时期也是令人不安的盟友，将把他们不稳定的关系置于;以色列准备进行可能的地面攻击;的进一步测试在巴勒斯坦加沙地带的问题上。

;

;在中东前进道路上经历了数月的紧张之后，这两位相识数十年的领导人在一场致命的、多方面的战争之后被迫建立战时伙伴关系。哈马斯武装分子从加沙袭击以色列。

;

;美国与华盛顿主要中东盟友以色列的关系近几个月因;白宫呼应以色列批评者;，他们组织了抗议活动，反对极右翼内塔尼亚胡政府限制最高法院权力的计划。

;

;但两位领导人的分歧要深刻得多

;

;作为总统，拜登经常强调支持独立的以色列和巴勒斯坦国家。政府官员表示，他在与内塔尼亚胡的每次谈话中都提到了这一点，同时要求他停止在被占领的约旦河西岸扩建犹太人定居点。

;

;内塔尼亚胡于 12 月底重返办公室，反对很快建立巴勒斯坦国家。并已批准为西岸定居者;数千套新住房; .

;

;Their often fraught history includes Biden's time as vice president during Barack Obama's presidency, when Netanyahu tried unsuccessfully to derail a 2015 US-backed Iran nuclear deal.

;

;Hamas is backed by Iran , Israel's regional arch-foe.

;

;By contrast, Netanyahu had a meeting of minds with Biden's Republican predecessor and potential 2024 opponent, Donald Trump, whose ideological embrace of the right-wing prime minister was accompanied by staunch pro -Israel policies.

;

;Netanyahu has nonetheless hedged and avoided taking sides in the US presidential campaign.

;

;After the weekend Hamas assault - the deadliest incursion since attacks by Egypt and Syria in the Yom Kippur war 50 years ago - Biden set aside differences in multiple phone calls with Netanyahu, saying his team was to give Israel "everything it needs" to fight the militant group, said a senior administration official.

;

;Biden assured Netanyahu of "rock solid" US support, scrambled to bolster Israel's military arsenal and dispatched a carrier strike group closer to Israel in a major show of support.

;

;In his public statements Biden has yet to say Israel should show restraint in its military response or expressed US concern for the Palestinian people, often part of White House reactions during previous crises.

;

;"The president emphasized that there is no justification whatsoever for terrorism, and all countries must stand united in the face of such brutal atrocities," the White House said of Biden's second call to Netanyahu on Sunday.

;

;Biden has directed his team to reach out to counterparts in the Gulf and neighboring countries to try to prevent a spiral into a wider war, especially focused on keeping the Iran-backed Lebanese group Hezbollah from opening a second front on Israel's northern border, administration officials said.

;

;While Biden appears to have given Netanyahu a free hand for now , the policy differences remain and he could change course if the Gaza death toll rises further and the fighting drags on, foreign policy experts predict.

;

;Israeli TV channels said the country's death toll from the Hamas attack had climbed to 900.

;

;In Hamas-controlled Gaza, Israel pressed on with its most intensive retaliatory strikes ever, which have killed more than 500 people since Saturday.

;

;"Eventually, if a conflict drags on for weeks or months, a number of US allies are going to lose patience and publicly call for it to end. At that point, you may see the US back channel to Israel to try and convince Jerusalem to bring the fight to an end," said Jonathan Panikoff, the US government's former deputy national intelligence officer for the Middle East who is now at the Atlantic Council think tank.

;

;Biden also faces the potential challenge of securing the release of an unknown number of missing Americans who may be held by Hamas as hostages.

;

;At home, Biden faces pressure on his right and his left, with Republican hardliners in Congress accusing him of emboldening Iran with a ;recent prisoner swap deal;, something the president's aides strongly deny.

;

;"If President Biden can stand with Ukraine for as long as it takes, I hope President Biden can stand with Israel for as long as it takes," said Republican Senator Tom Cotton, a foreign policy hawk, on Fox News' "Sunday Morning Futures."

;

;Some fellow Democrats, before the attacks, were asking Biden to scrutinize whether Israel merits the multibillion-dollar military aid package it receives each year, and calling for him to do more for the Palestinians.

;

;The powerful pro-Israel lobby, headed by AIPAC, is a major force in US politics, often backs Netanyahu and is expected to play a role in the 2024 election.

;

;Biden, 80, has called himself a "Zionist," and he and Netanyahu, 73, have both spoken of having a long friendship.

;

;But Biden went months without talking to Netanyahu this year. The Israeli leader was unhappy that he did not get a face-to-face meeting with Biden until Sept. 20 and it was not at the White House but in a New York hotel on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly.

;

;There, Biden expressed worries about the need for stability in the West Bank and settler violence that increased tensions with Palestinians, a senior administration official said.

;

;They appeared to find some common ground on a US push to broker a landmark agreement to open diplomatic relations between longtime foes Israel and Saudi Arabia. But the Hamas attack delivered a severe blow to that effort, leaving its future uncertain.

;

;Aaron David Miller, a Middle East expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said that despite Biden's problems with Netanyahu, "the people of Israel and security of Israel are deeply ingrained in Biden's DNA."

;

;"Biden is not in love with Bibi Netanyahu," he said, using the prime minister's nickname. "But he is in love with the state of Israel, the people of Israel and he'll do everything he can to protect the people of Israel."

;

;Billions of people could struggle to survive in periods of deadly, humid heat within this century as temperatures rise, particularly in some of the world's largest cities, from Delhi to Shanghai, according to research published on Monday.

;

;Towards the higher end of warming scenarios, potentially lethal combinations of heat and humidity could spread further including into areas such as the US Midwest, the authors of the report said.

;

;"It's very disturbing," study co-author Matthew Huber of Purdue University in the US state of Indiana told Reuters. "It's going to send a lot of people to emergency medical care."

;

;;The study; built on past research by Huber, George Mason University climatologist Daniel Vecellio and other scientists on the point at which heat and humidity combine to push the human body beyond its limits without shade or help from technologies such as air conditioning.

;

;It found that around 750 million people could experience one week per year of potentially deadly humid heat if temperatures rise 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) above preindustrial levels.

;

;At 3C (5.4F) of warming, more than 1.5 billion people would face such a threat, according to the paper published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS).

;

;The world is on track for 2.8C (5F) of warming by the year 2100 under current policies, according to the 2022 United Nations Emissions Gap report.

;

;While India, ;Pakistan; and the Gulf already have briefly touched dangerous humid heat in recent years, the study found it will afflict major cities from Lagos, Nigeria, to Chicago, Illinois if the world keeps heating up.

;

;"It's coming up in places that we didn't think about before," said Vecellio, highlighting rising risk in South America and Australia.

;

;At 4C of warming, Hodeidah, Yemen, would see around 300 days per year of potentially unsurvivable humid heat.

;

;To track such moist heat, scientists use a measurement known as ;"wet-bulb"; temperature.这是通过用浸水的布覆盖温度计来测量的。 The process of water evaporating from the cloth mirrors how the human body cools down with sweat.

;

;In a landmark 2010 ;study;, Huber proposed that a wet-bulb temperature of 35C (95F) persisting for six or more hours could be the conservative limit for the human body.

;

;Beyond this, people were likely to succumb to heat stress if they could not find a way to cool down.

;

;A decade later, a group of American scientists co-led by Vecellio put Huber's theory to the test by placing young, healthy adults in environmental ;chambers; with high wet-bulb temperatures.

;

;They found the limit was lower at between 30C (86F) and 31C (88F).

;

;Huber and Vecellio joined forces for Monday's study to apply this lower limit to the world under various future climate warming scenarios, ranging between 1.5C and 4C (2.7F and 7.2F).

;

;"This will be a critical benchmark for future studies," said atmospheric scientist Jane Baldwin of University of California Irvine who was not involved in the research.

;

;"Unfortunately, it's a somewhat grimmer picture than you would have gotten with the 35C limit," she said.

;

;Monday's research adds to a growing body of concern about dangerous wet-bulb temperatures.

;

;Another ;study; published last month in Sciences Advances used Vecellio's threshold alongside weather station data and climate models to reach a similar conclusion: that the geographic range and frequency of dangerous humid heat will increase rapidly under even moderate global warming.
